item.content:encoded: Image: Mundfish/Focus Entertainment, 4Divinity Echoes of Bioshock abound I‚Äôm 10 hours into Atomic Heart and the end is nowhere in sight. The game feels like it has only just finished its initial throat-clearing, now throwing open the door and hinting at some weird, sci-fi Soviet mysteries. It‚Äôs violent and familiar, like so many other first-person shooters. But as I barrel into the core of Atomic Heart, I wonder whether this game is what it appears to be ‚Äî or if it‚Äôs something much more intere...

item.content:encoded: Photo: Liane Hentscher/HBO Spoilers: It‚Äôs everywhere and everything HBO‚Äôs The Last of Us is a way to revisit the iconic and beloved video game of the same name ‚Äî to revel in the ways it‚Äôs both unchanged and entirely different. For dedicated fans of the game, the appeal of The Last of Us is not necessarily in being surprised by twists and turns of the story; rather, it‚Äôs to see the franchise in a new light, picking out the little details that point back to the original media. There‚Äôs plenty to ...

item.content:encoded: Photo: Liane Hentscher/HBO FEDRA, Fireflies, Hunters ‚Äî we break it down for you Life in The Last of Us is hard, to put it extremely, extremely mildly. Traveling anywhere is tough and involves siphoning off 20-year-old gas from abandoned cars. Zombies are everywhere, in increasingly terrifying forms. No one will laugh at your pun book. Perhaps worst of all, there‚Äôs the sense that danger is all around, even from the other people around you. The Last of Us universe is filled with factions, all cl...

item.content:encoded: Image: PUBG Studios/Krafton They‚Äôre probably not wrong, but are they pivoting in time? Tucked inside a report to investors, one sees the plans PUBG: Battlegrounds publisher Krafton has made to extricate itself from a battle royale market it helped create, but which seems to be plateauing, even for the Big Four (including Apex Legends, Fortnite, and Call of Duty: Warzone) that dominate the space. PUBG‚Äôs studio is working on an extraction shooter, a subgenre that looks like the way of the future...

item.content:encoded: Image: Blizzard Entertainment Blizzard announces dates for open beta and early access weekends Blizzard will hold a pair of playable open beta tests for Diablo 4 in March, the developer announced Saturday, confirming that early hands-on with the action role-playing game will be available on all platforms. Players who have pre-ordered Diablo 4 will get early access to the open beta on March 17-19, and the beta will be available to everyone on March 24-26. The open beta and early access weekends...

item.title: Would it be possible to create a tool to automatically diagram papers? | What's new
item.description: This is a somewhat experimental and speculative post. This week I was at the IPAM workshop on machine assisted proof that I was one of the organizers of. We had an interesting and diverse range of tal...
item.content:encoded: This is a somewhat experimental and speculative post. This week I was at the IPAM workshop on machine assisted proof that I was one of the organizers of. We had an interesting and diverse range of talks, both from computer scientists presenting the latest available tools to formally verify proofs or to automate various aspects [‚Ä¶]

item.title: Towards Geometric Deep Learning | The Gradient
item.description: Geometric Deep Learning is a term for approaches considering ML problems from the perspectives of symmetry and invariance. It provides a common blueprint for CNNs, GNNs, and Transformers. Here, we stu...
item.content:encoded: Geometric Deep Learning is a term for approaches considering ML problems from the perspectives of symmetry and invariance. It provides a common blueprint for CNNs, GNNs, and Transformers. Here, we study the history of GDL from ancient Greek geometry to Graph Neural Networks.

item.content:encoded: Photo: NBCUniversal Polygon spoke with Shigeru Miyamoto and Shinya Takahashi about bringing the park to life Super Nintendo World, which opens Friday at Universal Studios Hollywood, is a wholly unique and unforgettable new addition to the theme park. It brings Nintendo‚Äôs colorful worlds to life, allowing visitors to move through the space ‚Äî speckled with Thwomps, stacks of Goombas, spinning Koopa shells, and other iconic characters ‚Äî as if they were Mario and his friends. Walking through the l...

item.content:encoded: Image: Game Freak/The Pok√©mon Company via PokePlayz Plus a bunch of other bug fixes The Pok√©mon Company and developer Game Freak have a Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet update scheduled for the end of February, a patch that‚Äôs intended mostly to fix some bugs. Among those bugs is one that made one of the most powerful Pok√©mon even more powerful than intended. That Pok√©mon is Dondozo, specifically, Dondozo combined with Tatsugiri. The popular pair has a unique strategy unlike anything in previous Pok√©...

item.content:encoded: Photo: NBCUniversal Race Bowser and throw shells in Mario Kart: Bowser‚Äôs Challenge Super Nintendo World, which opened Friday at Universal Studios Hollywood, is a deeply immersive and interactive simulacrum of Mario‚Äôs world. Walking through a Warp Pipe immediately transports visitors into the Mushroom Kingdom, a brightly colored set wrapping around that section of the park to create the illusion of being inside a game. Koopas move back and forth along the green hills designed to look like class...

item.description: Posted by Parker Riley, Software Engineer, and Jan Botha, Research Scientist, Google Research Many languages spoken worldwide cover numerous regional varieties (sometimes called dialects), such as Bra...
item.content:encoded: Posted by Parker Riley, Software Engineer, and Jan Botha, Research Scientist, Google Research Many languages spoken worldwide cover numerous regional varieties (sometimes called dialects), such as Brazilian and European Portuguese or Mainland and Taiwan Mandarin Chinese. Although such varieties are often mutually intelligible to their speakers, there are still important differences. For example, the Brazilian Portuguese word for ‚Äúbus‚Äù is √¥nibus, while the European Portuguese word is autocarro. Y...

item.content:encoded: Posted by Haim Kaplan and Yishay Mansour, Research Scientists, Google Research Differential privacy (DP) machine learning algorithms protect user data by limiting the effect of each data point on an aggregated output with a mathematical guarantee. Intuitively the guarantee implies that changing a single user‚Äôs contribution should not significantly change the output distribution of the DP algorithm. However, DP algorithms tend to be less accurate than their non-private counterparts because satisf...

item.content:encoded: Posted by Kendra Byrne, Senior Product Manager, and Jie Tan, Staff Research Scientist, Robotics at Google (This is Part 6 in our series of posts covering different topical areas of research at Google. You can find other posts in the series here.) Within our lifetimes, we will see robotic technologies that can help with everyday activities, enhancing human productivity and quality of life. Before robotics can be broadly useful in helping with practical day-to-day tasks in people-centered spaces ...

item.title: Amplification at the quantum limit | Google AI Blog
item.description: Posted by Ted White and Ofer Naaman, Staff Research Scientists, Google Quantum AI The Google Quantum AI team is building quantum computers with superconducting microwave circuits, but much like a clas...
item.content:encoded: Posted by Ted White and Ofer Naaman, Staff Research Scientists, Google Quantum AI The Google Quantum AI team is building quantum computers with superconducting microwave circuits, but much like a classical computer the superconducting processor at the heart of these computers is only part of the story. An entire technology stack of peripheral hardware is required to make the quantum computer work properly. In many cases these parts must be custom designed, requiring extensive research and develo...

item.content:encoded: Posted by Jinsung Yoon and Sercan O. Arik, Research Scientists, Google Research, Cloud AI Team Anomaly detection (AD), the task of distinguishing anomalies from normal data, plays a vital role in many real-world applications, such as detecting faulty products from vision sensors in manufacturing, fraudulent behaviors in financial transactions, or network security threats. The explosion in deep learning a decade ago was catapulted in part by the convergence of new algorithms and architectures, a marked increase in data, and access to greater compute.
